subsc: Central government administration,Other social services,General agriculture, fishing and forestry sector

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project outcome has been
            unsatisfactory althougn the project was able to achieve
            meaningful but limited results from a poverty reduction
            standpoint. Lessons learned include the following: Civil
            servants should not be given a pivotal role in community
            micro-finance management. Implementation of similar
            activities in future projects should be handled by private
            nongovernmental organizations or other local organizations;
            local civil servants should have only a peripheral role.
            Decentralizing most management responsibilities can have a
            stimulating impact on project outreach; the involvement of
            many participants at the regional level has created strong
            ownership and left considerable experience and expertise at
            decentralized levels for similar operations in the future.
            Project monitoring, for the most part, was not well
            organized. The project's not having an independent
            impact evaluation system led to difficulties in assessing
            the impacts of various components components. Intensive and
            broad-based training is a pre-condition for adequate field
            implementation performance. A consistent and homogenous
            supervision team is needed on the Borrower and the Bank
            sides. The absence of interest rates on micro-credits was
            one of the weakest points in the project's design.
            Micro-credits repaid by communities must be recycled
            rapidly. A sustained participatory process can breed
            innovations, create ownership, and build capacities at the
            community level.
